To host a Laravel project on your server, you will also need to configure your web server to serve your Laravel project. This can be done by modifying the virtual host configuration file for your project and specifying the path to your project's `public` directory.

For example, if your Laravel project is located in the `/var/www/laravel` directory, you will need to modify the virtual host configuration file to specify the `/var/www/laravel/public` directory as the document root, like this:
```
<VirtualHost *:80>
    ServerName example.com
    ServerAdmin webmaster@example.com
    DocumentRoot /var/www/laravel/public

    <Directory /var/www/laravel/public>
        AllowOverride All
        Order allow,deny
        Allow from all
    </Directory>

    ErrorLog ${APACHE_LOG_DIR}/error.log
    CustomLog ${APACHE_LOG_DIR}/access.log combined
</VirtualHost>
```
Once you have modified the virtual host configuration file, you will need to restart your web server to apply the changes. For example, if you are using Apache, you can restart the server by running the following command:
```
sudo systemctl restart apache2
```
This will configure your web server to serve your Laravel project from the `public` directory. You can then access your Laravel project in a web browser by visiting the domain or IP address specified in the virtual host configuration.

Please note that these are just general instructions for configuring your web server to serve a Laravel project. The exact steps may vary depending on your specific server environment and the versions of the tools you are using.
